title: 114_hr3681
content: The Act is titled the "Improving Access to Emergency Psychiatric Care Act" and includes an extension and expansion of the Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration Project. The "Improving Access to Emergency Psychiatric Care Act" extends and expands the Medicaid Emergency Psychiatric Demonstration Project for a period of 3 consecutive years, with a temporary extension option for selected states until September 30, 2016. The Secretary must ensure that a State's participation in the demonstration project does not increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Chief Actuary of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must certify that the extension for the State will not increase net program spending. The Secretary is required to notify each selected State of these projections by March 13, 2012. The Secretary may allow eligible States to continue participating in the demonstration project through December 31, 2019, if it is projected not to increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary may expand the number of eligible States participating in the demonstration project through December 31, 2019, if the Chief Actuary certifies that it will not increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary can expand the eligible States in the demonstration project until December 31, 2019, if the Chief Actuary certifies that it will not increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary must provide notice of projections to each State participating in the project. The Secretary can expand eligible States in the demonstration project until December 31, 2019, with notice of projections provided to each State participating. States must apply to be added to the project, with determinations and certifications made by August 31, 2016 for existing participants and additional States. The Secretary annually reviews participating States' demonstration project expenditures to ensure budget neutrality. If a State's net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act increases as a result of participation, excess expenditures are treated as overpayments. The Secretary reviews States' project expenditures for budget neutrality under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Excess spending is treated as overpayments. Amendments to funding include removing limitations on Federal funding and extending expenditure deadlines. Amendments to funding include removing limitations on Federal funding and extending expenditure deadlines. In paragraph (4), adjustments are made for eligible States, with additional payments during specified periods. The Secretary reviews States' project expenditures for budget neutrality under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Excess spending is treated as overpayments. Amendments to funding include removing limitations on Federal funding and extending expenditure deadlines. Payments to States for emergency psychiatric demonstration services during the extension period are considered medical assistance under the State plan. Recommendations to Congress regarding extension are also included. The Secretary will provide recommendations to Congress on the extension and expansion of the demonstration project by September 30, 2016, including whether it should continue and be expanded to additional States. Additionally, recommendations on permanent extension and nationwide expansion will be submitted by April 1, 2019. The Secretary will recommend whether to permanently continue or expand the demonstration project based on quality measures, including a certification from the Chief Actuary of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will only permanently continue or expand a demonstration project in a State if it does not increase net program spending under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Congressional approval is required for any continuation or expansion after December 31, 2019. Each State's participation must comply with quality measures for the project to proceed. The project must adhere to budget neutrality requirements, with any excess expenditures treated as overpayment under title XIX of the Social Security Act. $100,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2015 to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Program Management Account for this purpose. Section 2707 of the Act is amended to allow for nationwide availability if the Secretary recommends expanding the demonstration project on a national basis. The demonstration project may be expanded nationally, with any State that applies deemed eligible to participate. The heading for subsection (f) will now include "Recommendations". The amendments will take effect upon enactment of the Act.
